ijdk.lang

Class Range

  • java.lang.Object
    • ijdk.lang.Range
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<Range>, java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Integer>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Range

    public class Range
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Comparable<Range>, java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Integer>
    A range of integers, inclusive. Supports iteration and array expansion.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Range(java.lang.Integer first, java.lang.Integer last)
      Creates a range of first through last (i.e., inclusive).

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      int compareTo(Range other)
      Compares this range to the other.
      boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
      Returns whether this range equals the other.
      java.lang.Integer getFirst() 
      java.lang.Integer getLast()
      Returns the last number of the range.
      int hashCode()
      Returns the hashCode for this range.
      boolean includes(java.lang.Integer n)
      Returns whether the given number is within the range.
      java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Integer> iterator()
      Returns an iterator for the range.
      java.lang.Integer[] toArray()
      Returns the range as an array.
      java.lang.Integer[] toExpandedArray()
      Returns the range as an expanded array, with elements for each number within the range.
      java.lang.String toString()
      Returns the range as a string.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, finalize, getClass, notify, notifyAll, wait, wait, wait

      • Methods inherited from interface java.lang.Iterable

        forEach, spliterator

    • Constructor Detail

      • Range

        public Range(java.lang.Integer first,
             java.lang.Integer last)
        Creates a range of first through last (i.e., inclusive). First can be less than, equal to, or greater than, last.

    • Method Detail

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Integer> iterator()
        Returns an iterator for the range. Usage: 
          Range rg = new Range(11, 14);
  for (Integer i : rg) { // block called with 11, 12, 13, 14
  }
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Integer>

      • getFirst

        public java.lang.Integer getFirst()

      • getLast

        public java.lang.Integer getLast()
        Returns the last number of the range.

      • includes

        public boolean includes(java.lang.Integer n)
        Returns whether the given number is within the range. Returns false if the first value is greater than the last value in the range.

      • toArray

        public java.lang.Integer[] toArray()
        Returns the range as an array. For example: 
          Range rg = new Range(11, 14);
  Integer[] ary = rg.toArray(); // ary == new Integer[] { 11, 14 }
        See Also:
        toExpandedArray

      • toExpandedArray

        public java.lang.Integer[] toExpandedArray()
        Returns the range as an expanded array, with elements for each number within the range. For example: 
          Range rg = new Range(3, 7);
  Integer[] ary = rg.toExpandedArray(); // ary == new Integer[] { 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 }
        See Also:
        toArray

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
        Returns whether this range equals the other.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Returns the hashCode for this range. Thus ranges can be used as keys in a HashMap.
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class java.lang.Object

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns the range as a string.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(Range other)
        Compares this range to the other. A range is less than another range if either the first or last elements are less than the other's. A range is greater than another range if either the first or last element are greater than the other's.
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<Range>
